justification: “The foundational experimental paradigm of behavioural decision-making research consists in making choices between ‘lotteries’ or ‘gambles’ …” – indicating that people’s risk preferences are assessed through their choices among lotteries.

“Computationally, behaviour in multi-armed bandit problems is generally well-captured by associative or reinforcement learning processes” – showing that the bandit task is the instrument used to measure reinforcement-learning variables.

measured_by: description-based decision task with explicit probability displays
justification: “In pure description, two options are presented with explicit probability distribution of outcomes… Subjective probability is reflected by a probability weighting function (here denoted π)” – the explicit-probability (description) task is what elicits the weighting function.

“In description-based choices, a behavioural hallmark of loss aversion … is the reflection effect, where subjects are risk-averse in the gain domain and risk-seeker in the loss domain.” – the reflection-effect task operationalises loss aversion.

measured_by: dual-learning-rate reinforcement-learning model applied to experience-based choices
justification: “Risk-seeking behaviour in experience-based studies can be computationally explained by an increased sensitivity to positive (compared to negative) prediction errors (‘positivity’ bias)… demonstrating a stronger impact of past positive outcome in choices using either model-free and model-based measures” – i.e., asymmetry in estimated learning rates from the RL model indexes the positivity bias.
